     2guid: aitw-040
     3title: "Applying 12-Factor Principles to Coding Agent SDKs"
     4description: |
     5  We've done a lot of talking in the last few months about prompting coding agents and context engineering w/ markdown files, but today we'll talk about how to squeeze even more out of agents by using agent loops as smaller elements of a deterministic workflow.
     6
     7  In this session we'll cover:
     8
     9  - using the claude agent sdk to stitch together microagent workflows
    10  - accumulating user rules across context windows
    11  - json state and structured outputs with zod
    12  - session continuation and forking vs. direct compaction

file.content:
---
guid: aitw-040
title: "Applying 12-Factor Principles to Coding Agent SDKs"
description: |
  We've done a lot of talking in the last few months about prompting coding agents and context engineering w/ markdown files, but today we'll talk about how to squeeze even more out of agents by using agent loops as smaller elements of a deterministic workflow.

  In this session we'll cover:

  - using the claude agent sdk to stitch together microagent workflows
  - accumulating user rules across context windows
  - json state and structured outputs with zod
  - session continuation and forking vs. direct compaction
event_link: https://luma.com/12-factors-to-coding-agents
eventDate: 2026-01-13T18:00:00Z
media:
  url: null
  type: video/youtube
links:
  code: https://github.com/ai-that-works/ai-that-works/tree/main/2026-01-13-applying-12-factor-principles-to-coding-agent-sdks
  # no youtube link here yet
season: 2
episode: 40
event_type: episode
---

file.content:
You are implementing a single step of BurritoOps, a SaaS platform for burrito delivery operators.

0. Familiarize yourself with the source code in this directory

1. Read IMPLEMENTATION_PLAN.md and implement the single highest priority TASK

2. Ensure all tests and linting pass, then update IMPLEMENTATION_PLAN.md with your progress

3. Use `git add -A` and `git commit -m "..."` to commit your changes

Ensure implementation steps are organized around verifiable milestones, and that you have either a) validated them or b) documented what's not working.

Key constraints:
- One step per loop. Do ONE thing well, then stop.
- If tests fail, fix them before moving on
- If you get stuck, document the blocker and stop

content.thinking:
Good! Now I have a solid understanding of the project:

1. It's a demo project for an "AI That Works" episode about applying 12-factor principles to coding agent SDKs
2. It uses the Claude Agent SDK (@anthropic-ai/claude-agent-sdk)
3. It has several demo scripts:
   - `index.ts` - Basic hello world demo
   - `chat.ts` - Interactive chat demo
   - `structured-planning.ts` - Structured planning with Zod
   - `structured-planning-with-json.ts` - Structured planning with JSON
   - `ralph.ts` - RALPH autonomous development loop
   - `baml-parsing.ts` - BAML parsing examples
4. It uses BAML (BoundaryML) for structured data extraction
5. The project is related to BurritoOps (a demo SaaS platform for burrito delivery)
6. There's already a RALPH.md file with instructions

Now I should check if there's already a README:
I see there's a structured planning script that does what I'm doing right now! It explores the codebase and asks clarifying questions. Let me check if there's an existing README:
Great! There's NO README file yet, so we need to create one from scratch. Now I have enough information about the project. Let me also quickly check the BAML files to understand what they do:

content.content:
1// Structured types for parsing design discussion output
     2
     3class DesignOutput {
     4    summary string @description("Summary of what we understand so far")
     5    openDesignQuestions string[] @description("Questions that still need answers")
     6}
     7
     8// Parse unstructured design discussion into structured output
     9function ParseDesignDiscussion(raw_text: string) -> DesignOutput {
    10    client Claude
    11    prompt #"
    12        Parse the following design discussion into structured JSON.
    13        Extract a summary of decisions made and any open questions.
    14
    15        Text:
    16        ---
    17        {{ raw_text }}
    18        ---
    19
    20        {{ ctx.output_format }}
    21    "#
    22}
    23
